review.title: How Important is Syntactic Parsing Accuracy? An Empirical Evaluation on Sentiment Analysis
review.abstract: Syntactic parsing, the process of obtaining the internal structure of sentences in natural languages, is a crucial task for artificial intelligence applications that need to extract meaning from natural language text or speech. Sentiment analysis is one example of application for which parsing has recently proven useful.
histories: 19 pages. Submitted to Artificial Intelligence Review
19 pages. Accepted for publication in Artificial Intelligence Review. DOI and link pending
19 pages. Accepted for publication in Artificial Intelligence Review. This update only adds the DOI link to comply with journal's terms
review.COMMENTS: 19 pages. Submitted to Artificial Intelligence Review

metadata.title: How Important is Syntactic Parsing Accuracy? An Empirical Evaluation on Sentiment Analysis

sections.text: There has been significant progress in the accuracy of parsing algorithms in recent years. In this article, we conduct an empirical task-oriented evaluation to determine how parsing accuracy affects the performance of a state-of-the-art sentiment analysis system that determines the polarity of sentences from their parse trees. Specifically, we evaluate the system using four known dependency parsers, including both current models with state-of-the-art accuracy and more innacurate models that require less computing resources. Experiments show that all parsers achieve similarly good results in the sentiment analysis task without their accuracy having a relevant impact on the results. As parsing is currently a task with relatively high computer costs, which vary greatly between algorithms, this suggests that sentiment analysts and users should evaluate the speed over accuracy in selecting a parser, and parsing researchers should examine models that further improve the speed, even at some cost.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Having successfully understood the meaning of sentences in human languages, this is a long-standing key goal in artificial intelligence (AI). Although full understanding is still a long way off, recent advances in natural language processing (NLP) are an important step in this process, as the predicate argument structure of sentences contains important information to successfully understand their semantics. A text mining system that needs to generate a report on customer reviews of phones could include statements such as "the iPhone is much better than the HTC 10" and "the HTC 10 is much better than the iPhone," which are identical in terms of the individual words they contain. It is the syntactic structure - in this case to be the subject and attribute of the verb - that tells us which of the phones are preferred.

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: We provide an overview of research into parsing and sentiment analyses relevant to this study.2.1 ParsingaDifferent linguistic theories define different ways in which the syntactic structure of a sentence can be described. In particular, the vast majority of natural language parsers in literature adhere to one of two dominant representations. In the grammar of constituencies (or phrase structure grammar), sentences are analysed by dividing them into segments, which in turn are broken down into smaller constituencies, as in the example of Figure 1. In dependency grammar, the syntax of a sentence is represented by directed binary relationships between its words, which are called dependencies that are most useful when labelled with their syntactic roles, as in Figure 2. Each of these types of representation provides different information about the sentence, and it is not possible to create a complete map of constituencies to represent or vice versa (Kahane and Mazziotta 2015).

sections.heading: 3 Materials and Methods
sections.text: 3.1 Parsing Systems - MaltParser: Introduced by Nivre et al (2007), this system can be used to train transition-based parsers with greedy deterministic search. Although its accuracy has fallen short of the state of the art, it is still widely used, probably due to its maturity and solid documentation. In addition, due to its greedy nature, MaltParser uses a standard arc-eager (transition-based) parsing algorithm, which we use in conjunction with the feature optimization tool MaltOptimizer1 (Ballesteros and Nivre 2012) to optimize the parameters and train a suitable model. The trained MaltParser model uses a standard arc-eager (transition-based) parsing algorithm, where in each step the motion is selected to apply possible transitions previously obtained from a model that is faster to use than the linear model.

sections.heading: 4 Results
sections.text: Table 1 shows how much time each parser consumes to analyze the Pang and Lee (2005) corpus, and how much time it consumes overall when the SA system runs on it. Tables 3, 4, and 5 show the accuracy that each parser needs to analyze the Pang and Lee (2005) corpus when the results of each parser are used as input to the syntax-based sentiment analysis system.3 We take accuracy as a reference for the SA systems, as it is the most appropriate metric in this case since the three corpora are balanced. Specifically, we compare performance when no syntactic rules are used (which would correspond to a lexicon-based system that only summarizes the semantic orientation of individual words) in terms of what is achieved when different rules are added. The goal is to determine whether different parsers manage relevant linguistic phenomena in different ways.

sections.heading: 5 Discussion
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to survive on their own.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: In this article, we conducted a task-oriented empirical evaluation to determine the relevance of analyzing accuracy to the primary challenge of sentiment analysis: polarity classification. We selected English as the target language and trained a number of standard and freely available parsers on the Universal Dependency Treebank v2.0 (McDonald et al 2013). The results of such parsers on various standard sentiment corpora are then used as input for a state-of-the-art and syntax-based system aimed at classifying the polarity of these texts. Experimental results allow us to draw two interesting and promising conclusions: (1) a better labeled / unlabeled attachment score when parsing does not necessarily imply significantly better accuracy in polarity classification when using syntax-based algorithms and (2) the parsing for sentiment analysis should focus on speed rather than accuracy as we have obtained from the LAS by using an accuracy of about 80% of the initial one (the LAS is high).

Most dependency parsing systems in the literature can be grouped into two broad categories (McDonald and Nivre 2007): graph-based and transition-based (shift-reduce) parsers.

Unfortunately, exact inference has been shown to be intractable for models that support arbitrary non-projectivity, except under strong independence assumptions (McDonald and Satta 2007) which enable parsing in quadratic time with maximum spanning tree algorithms (McDonald et al 2005), but severely limit the expressivity of the feature models that can be used.

This problem is alleviated by instead performing beam search (Zhang and Nivre 2011) or dynamic programming (Huang and Sagae 2010; Kuhlmann et al 2011) to explore transition sequences, but this increases the computational cost.

Jia et al (2009) and Asmi and Ishaya (2012) defined a set of syntax-based rules for identifying and handling negation on natural language texts represented as dependency trees.

Jia et al (2009) and Asmi and Ishaya (2012) defined a set of syntax-based rules for identifying and handling negation on natural language texts represented as dependency trees. They also pointed out the advantage of using this kind of methods with respect to traditional lexicon-based perspectives in tasks such as opinion mining or information retrieval. Poria et al (2014) posed a set of syntax-based patterns for a concept-level approach to determine how the sentiment flows from concept to concept, assuming that such concepts present in texts are represented as nodes of a dependency tree.

– Stanford RNN Parser (Chen and Manning 2014): The most popular among the recent wave of transition-based parsers that employ neural networks, it can achieve robust accuracy in spite of using greedy deterministic search.

This fact is expected, as there is a well-known tradeoff between speed and accuracy in the spectrum of parsing algorithms, with one extreme at greedy search approaches that scan and parse the sentence in a single pass but are prone to error propagation, and the other at exact search algorithms that guarantee finding the highest-scoring parse under a rich statistical model, but are prohibitively slow (Choi and McCallum 2013; Volokh 2013; Gómez-Rodŕıguez 2016).

metadata.abstractText: Syntactic parsing, the process of obtaining the internal structure of sentences in natural languages, is a crucial task for artificial intelligence applications that need to extract meaning from natural language text or speech. Sentiment analysis is one example of application for which parsing has recently proven useful. In recent years, there have been significant advances in the accuracy of parsing algorithms. In this article, we perform an empirical, task-oriented evaluation to determine how parsing accuracy influences the performance of a state-of-the-art sentiment analysis system that determines the polarity of sentences from their parse trees. In particular, we evaluate the system using four well-known dependency parsers, including both current models with state-of-the-art accuracy and more innacurate models which, however, require less computational resources. The experiments show that all of the parsers produce similarly good results in the sentiment analysis task, without their accuracy having any relevant influence on the results. Since parsing is currently a task with a relatively high computational cost that varies strongly between algorithms, this suggests that sentiment analysis researchers and users should prioritize speed over accuracy when choosing a parser; and parsing researchers should investigate models that improve speed further, even at some cost to accuracy.
